Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The effects of three-dimensional fluid flows on front propagation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical abstract

Fluid flows play a crucial role in the behavior of many physical, chemical, geological, astrophysical and biological processes. During the past ten years, the PI's research group has done numerous experiments on the behavior of reaction fronts in simple, two-dimensional (2D) fluid flows. Results from those experiments have led to development of a theory that predicts the existence of "burning invariant manifolds" (BIMs) in the flow that act as invisible barriers that block the motion of reaction fronts. The experiments funded by this grant will extend those studies to three-dimensional (3D) flows. In particular, we will explore whether BIMs in 3D flows still act as barriers that impede the motion of reaction fronts. Ultimately, these experiments may lead to a better understanding of blooms of plankton in the oceans; more efficient chemical reactors, especially in micro-scale devices; processes in plasma flows that might lead to economical fusion-based electrical generation; the role of cellular-scale flows in biological processes including morphogenesis in a developing embryo; detonation of supernova explosions; and the effects of moving populations on the spreading of a disease. This is an RUI (Research at Undergraduate Institutions) grant; consequently, all of this research will be done with undergraduate students who will play an active role in all aspects of the studies, including experimental design, building and testing of the apparatus, data collection and analysis, and publication and presentation of the results. These will be the first real research experiences for most of these students, and will play an important role in their development as scientists.

Technical Abstract

This grant will fund experiments that will study the behavior of reaction fronts in three-dimensional (3D) fluid flows. This is an issue with applications to a wide range of front-producing systems in physics, chemistry, biology and geology. The PI has extensive experience doing similar experiments (all with undergraduates) in 2D flows. Results from those experiments led to the development of a theory that identifies "burning invariant manifolds" (BIMs) in the flow that act as barriers that block reaction fronts. The proposed experiments will extend those studies to 3D flows composed of nested chains of vortices. Reaction fronts will be produced by the excitable Belousov-Zhabotinsky chemical reaction which has been shown to exhibit dynamics similar to those for a wide range of front-producing systems. Questions addressed by this research will include: (a) whether the BIM theory can be extended to the full 3D problem; (b) whether barriers similar to the BIMs in the 2D flows still exist to front propagation in 3D flows; and (c) whether reaction barriers in 3D flows can be destroyed by weak time dependence. This is an RUI (Research at Undergraduate Institutions) grant; consequently, all of this research will be done with undergraduate students who will play an active role in all aspects of the studies, including experimental design, building and testing of the apparatus; data collection and analysis; and publication and presentation of the results. These will be the first real research experiences for most of these students, and will play an important role in their development as scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A large number of natural and industrial processes involve a "reaction" that changes something into something else.  For example, a reaction between wood and oxygen turns the wood into ash.  Or a reaction between a person and a virus can turn a healthy person into a sick person. In extended systems, reactions proceed via the movement of a reaction "front" that sweeps across the system.  Examples of propagating reaction fronts include a fire that sweeps across a forest, burning trees in its wake; the spreading of a disease in a population of people; blooms of algae that invade coastal regions; and various flow-enhanced processes in developing embryos.  The behavior of reaction fronts may also play a significant role in developing nuclear fusion as an energy source.

The research supported by this grant focused on the effects of fluid flows on the behavior of moving reaction fronts. Previously, our experimental research group -- in conjunction with a theoretical group at the University of California at Merced -- had discovered that fronts moving in two-dimensional (2D) flows were blocked by invisible barriers called burning invariant manifolds (BIMs). Figure 1 shows an example of these barriers for a chemical reaction in a flow composed of an array of vortices (whirlpools), along with the theoretical predictions of the BIMs for a reaction front in the same flow. 

But most fluid flows are three-dimensional (3D), and the structure of barriers can be very different in 3D flows than in 2D flows. The experiments funded by this grant studied reactions in a 3D flow composed of the combination of a horizontal and vertical chain of vortices (Figure 2), driven by magnetic forcing from magnet chains below and on the side of the cell. We found clear evidence for both tube-like and sheet-like barriers in the experiments (Figures 3a and b), and we found that a 3D version of the BIM theory successfully predicted the form of these barriers (Figures 3c and d). 

A better understanding of how different fluid flows affect the shape and locations of these barriers should lay the foundation for developing a general theory of how reaction fronts move in a flow. This can have applications for a wide range of systems, including the development of efficient microfluidic ("Lab-on-a-chip") chemical processors and medical diagnostics, understanding how ocean flows affect harmful algal blooms, and potentially even developing better models for how the spread of a disease is affected by the movement of people in a population.

The research funded by this grant also included preliminary studies of the behavior of swimming organisms in a fluid flow. Although seemingly different from reaction fronts, it turns out that almost the same theory that predicts barriers for reaction fronts also predicts barriers that inhibit the motion of swimmers in a flow. Figure 4 shows bacteria swimming in a two-vortex flow. Those experiments are still in progress; if we are able to show similar barrier behavior in two very different systems, it will emphasize the universality of one-way barriers for a wide range of fluid systems in nature and in industry.

Our studies all involved undergraduate students, who played a significant role in all aspects of the research, including planning of the experiments, construction and testing of the apparatus, data collection and analysis, publication of the results, and presentation at national conferences.  The students supported by this grant interacted with others in our department?s REU program and in the university?s "STEM Scholars" program for entering first-year students. These research experiences provided crucial developmental opportunities for the students as they made decisions about whether to pursue careers in research, industry or any other field.
